law.catch_line: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, an authority has the powers set forth in this section...

text.section: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, an authority has the powers set forth in this section.

An authority may also:
prepare, carry out, acquire, own, lease, and operate housing projects in its area of operation;
provide for the construction, reconstruction, improvement, alteration, or repair of a housing project;
provide directly or arrange or contract for a person or governmental unit to furnish facilities or services, including drug rehabilitation, elderly or child day care, and other social services for or in connection with:
a housing project; or
the residents of a housing project; and
notwithstanding any other law, require in a contract in connection with a housing project that the contractor and any subcontractors comply with:
requirements about minimum wages and maximum hours of labor; and
any conditions that the State or federal government attaches to financial aid for the housing project.

section.section: When an authority has money that is held in a reserve or sinking fund or is not needed for immediate disbursement, the authority may invest the money in property or securities in which savings banks may invest.
An authority may purchase its bonds at not more than their principal amount and accrued interest, all bonds so purchased to be canceled.

text.section:
Acting through one or more of its commissioners or designees, an authority may also:
examine, investigate, hear testimony, and take evidence at public or private hearings on any matter material to its duties;
make findings and recommendations about any property where conditions pose a danger to the public health, morals, safety, or welfare; and
make those findings and recommendations available to appropriate governmental units, including those that in its area of operation have the duty to:
abate or require the correction of nuisances or like conditions; or
demolish unsafe or unsanitary structures.

An authority may also establish and control not-for-profit entities, including corporations and limited liability companies, that may own, operate, and take steps necessary or convenient to develop or otherwise undertake housing projects in the authority's area of operation.

section.section:
In the manner provided under Title 12 of the Real Property Article or any other applicable statutory law, an authority may also acquire by eminent domain real property that the authority considers necessary for its purposes under this Division II, if:
the authority adopts a resolution declaring that the acquisition of the real property is necessary for those purposes; and
the legislative body and the chief elected official approve.
Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, property devoted to a public use may similarly be acquired by eminent domain.
Real property that belongs to the State or a political subdivision may not be acquired without the consent of the State or the political subdivision.

text.section:
An authority may also:
borrow money and accept grants and other financial assistance from the political subdivision, the State, and the federal government and accept grants from nongovernmental sources for a housing project in its area of operation;
take over, lease, or manage a housing project or undertaking constructed, financed, or owned by the political subdivision, the State, or the federal government; and
comply with conditions and enter into mortgages, trust indentures, leases, and agreements as may be necessary or desirable.
